frontmatter.title: 7. Update data with mutations
frontmatter.description: Learn how to update data with the Mutation component

children.value: With Warthog Client, updating data from a graph API is as simple as calling a function. Additionally, the Warthog Client cache is smart enough to automatically update in most cases. In this section, we'll learn how to use the

properties.ariaLabel: what is a mutation component permalink

children.value: component is another important building block in an Warthog app. It's a React component that provides a function to execute a GraphQL mutation. Additionally, it tracks the loading, completion, and error state of that mutation.
is very similar to fetching data with a
component. The main difference is that the first argument to the
that actually triggers the mutation when it is called. The second argument to the
render prop function is a result object that contains loading and error state, as well as the return value from the mutation. Let's see an example:

and copy the code below so we can start building out the login screen:

function to wrap our GraphQL mutation so it can be parsed into an AST. We're also importing some components that we'll use in the next steps. Now, let's bind this mutation to our component by passing it to the

properties.ariaLabel: attach authorization headers to the request permalink

children.value: Attach authorization headers to the request
We're almost done completing our login feature! Before we do, we need to attach our token to the GraphQL request's headers so our server can authorize the user. To do this, navigate to
and replace the code below for the constructor:
allows us to read the token from
and attach it to the request's headers each time a GraphQL operation is made.
In the next section, we'll add the
form to the user interface. For that, we need to learn how Warthog allows us to manage local state in our app.
